comment_25:
Good job spreading love, folks.
Do me a favor...do The Beatles a favor...do John Lennon a favor...do everyone a favor...do yourself a favor:
LOVE...just love...everybody...including yourself...please.

"Nothing you can sing that can't be sung"
You aren't new.  Stop holding your pride in your identity and differences.  Enjoy all of the differences of all people.  Stop fighting because someone is either better than you or completely opposite in some way or another because everyone is.  Embrace and love the differences in others and share your interests that are similar.

Looks mean shit.  Cars mean shit.  War is shit.  Religion means shit.  Everything means shit, but LOVE.  All you need is love...and not that lame, pathetic dream-love...REAL LOVE, unconditional, friendly, helpful, true, pure love.  Forgive, never forget, learn, understand, and turn that knowledge into compassion: a love that CAN NEVER DIE.

comment_36:
"Invention in F Major" written by Johann Sebastian Bach is played towards the end, with brass and somewhat transposed. They also juxtaposed the round that Bach had intended, causing the instruments to clash a bit more, and sound a little harsher. After the Invention was referenced (briefly) another type of music was referenced... "Big Band" I suppose. 

Not that these excerpts mean anything significant, but perhaps Bach provided the Beatles with at least one piece of inspiration.
comment_37:
I hate to burst your bubble folks - this song is not really about "love and peace" like you all think and like the hippy movement seemed to want it to be.  Read Hunter Thompson's Authorized Biography of The Beatles (aptly called, The Beatles) and the boys from Liverpool tell you themselves the inspiration for this song (first heard during the first ever World Wide Live Broadcast from Hawaii using the first ever Communications Satelite - an invention of Arthur C. Clarkes who was among the many famous you will see if you watch the video).

Here it is:  Every phrase is a statement (paraphrased most likely) made to the band by the at the time deceased Brian Epstein, their manager who took the band to fame by molding their image.  There's nothing you can't do, there's no one you can't be, there's no point in getting all political, keep the image and sing love songs.  That was Brian's message to the band - this song was their message to themselves and the world that they were now a new band.  Read the book.  The line at the end, from "She Loves You" (an early Beatle hit) was sarcastically added to point out the type of music that the band was no longer interested in creating.

As a side note, Paul McCartney's "Silly Little Love Song" was in reference to this - suggesting it was all Lenon's idea to vere from the formula.  The old Lennon vs McCartney thing I s'pose.

comment_65:
I've always felt that the lyrics in the verses suggest that being ambitious and achieving things iis overrated and not as important as finding real love.
I think that there are three key words missing in the lyrics but implied in the sentiment: Those words are "By someone else..."

So in my mind what John Lennon is trying to say is:

There's nothing you can do that can't be done...by someone else.
Nothing you can sing that can't be sung...by someone else.
There's nothing you can make that can't be made...by someone else.
No one you can save that can't be saved...by someone else.
There's nothing you can know that isn't known...by someone else.
Nothing you can show that can't be shown...by someone else. 

But what you can put your efforts into is:
Learning how "to be you in time"...accept where "you're meant to be...and embrace the notion that "all you need is love."
